snippet: Spain expelled its Jews in 1492. Five hundred years later, it is near offering their descendants citizenship.
abstract: Spanish Parliament, in gesture of conciliation for expulsion of Jews during Inquisition in 1492, is set to approve bill that will offer citizenship to anyone of Sephardic Jewish heritage; Justice Ministry has already registered 3,000 applications, testament to keen interest from foreign Jews, particularly in Israel.

byline.original: By ISABEL KERSHNER and RAPHAEL MINDER
byline.contributor: Isabel Kershner reported from Jerusalem, and Raphael Minder from Madrid. Irit Pazner Garshowitz contributed reporting from Jerusalem.

lead_paragraph: Spain expelled its Jews in 1492. Five hundred years later, it is near offering their descendants citizenship.

headline.main: Prospect of Spanish Citizenship Appeals to Descendants of Jews Expelled in 1492
headline.print_headline: Prospect of Spanish Citizenship Appeals to Descendants of Jews Expelled in 1492
